title: 112_hr3464
content: The Act is titled the "Sandra Day O'Connor Civic Learning Act of 2011." Congress suggests increasing the sample size of students tested in the National Assessment of Educational Progress for better data analysis. An amendment is made to provide Civic Learning Grants under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary can award grants to promote civic learning and engagement. Funds must be used for programs that promote equity and access for diverse student populations. The Secretary can award grants for innovative civic learning programs that prioritize equity and access for underserved students. These programs focus on engaging students through various approaches like service learning and online platforms, while also emphasizing scalability through cost-effective implementation and alignment with educational standards. The curr_chunk discusses accountability in civic education programs, including assessment of student outcomes, techniques for underserved populations, and evaluation of teachers. Eligible entities are defined as nonprofit educational organizations. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to sections 2342 and 2343 of the Act related to civic education programs, focusing on organizations experienced in curriculum development for students in countries other than the United States. Amendments are made to sections 2342 and 2343 of the Act regarding civic education programs, emphasizing organizations with expertise in curriculum development for international students. The table of contents of the Act is amended by removing sections 2341 through 2346 and adding new items. Authorization of appropriations for civic learning grants and cooperative civic education and economic education exchange programs under sections 2341 and 2342 of the Act. $28.5 million for grants and $1.5 million for programs are authorized for fiscal years 2013 through 2018.
